conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—I'm Student_B. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m excited about the academic environment and opportunities your school offers. I would like to formally apply and would be honored to join if accepted.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, but I have relatively low priority there (4th), so an early application risks rejection if higher-priority students apply. At School_C, I am ranked 1st, making acceptance very likely if I apply now. Since School_C is still my 3rd choice and securing a strong, stable match early is valuable in a one-seat-per-school market, I will apply to School_C to lock in a guaranteed placement rather than gamble on School_A or School_B.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and your interest in School_C. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_C. Please confirm your intent to enroll and we’ll share the next steps for enrollment.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_B is #1 on School_C's true priority list. They have applied in round 1 and we have quota 1 available. Accepting immediately secures our top-choice student and there is no higher-priority candidate to wait for. Therefore, accept to lock in the best possible match.

conversation.message: Dear School_E Admissions, I’m Student_A. I’m very interested in joining School_E and believe I would be a strong fit for your community. If admitted, I would be ready to commit and enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but I have the lowest priority there, so an immediate application is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. To maximize my final match quality, I should target a school where I have strong priority and can secure an early acceptance. School_E ranks me #1 in its priority list, so applying there now likely locks in a good match (my 4th choice) rather than risking ending up with my last choice or unmatched after losing competition at B/C/A.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and your clear commitment to School_E. We are pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_E. Please confirm your enrollment steps as instructed by the admissions office.

conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_E’s true priority list. They have already applied with commitment language, and accepting now secures our top-choice match given quota=1. No higher-ranked candidate exists, so there is no strategic benefit to waiting.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_C and I’m formally applying. School_B is my first-choice school because I value its academic environment and would be excited to contribute and commit if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately. I have relatively strong priority at School_B (ranked 3rd after Student_E and Student_B). Even if competition is high, applying now maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before the seat is taken.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your thoughtful application and for naming School_B as your first choice. After reviewing applications this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest in School_B and wish you the very best in the process.
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I received applications from Student_C and Student_D; C is ranked above D, so if I must choose between them now, C is preferable. However, Student_E (my top choice) and Student_B (second) have not yet applied; accepting C now would fill my only seat and prevent matching with a higher-priority student who may apply in later rounds. Given the game allows up to 30 rounds and other students’ preferences show Student_A and Student_D list School_B first and Student_C lists School_B first, while Student_B prefers School_A first and Student_E does not rank School_B highly (last), the likelihood of receiving Student_E is low, but Student_B could come to School_B if rejected by School_A. Still, with only one seat, holding out is valuable because I can always accept C later if they remain available. Therefore, reject C now to preserve the option for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: School_B is my first choice, and I’m very eager to enroll. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat and would accept immediately. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B. Although School_B’s priority list ranks me behind Student_E, Student_B, and Student_C, there is still a chance they apply elsewhere first (Student_B prefers School_A; Student_E prefers School_C; Student_C also prefers School_B). To maximize the chance of landing my top option, I should apply immediately and signal strong commitment rather than delay with small talk.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your first choice. We appreciate your clear commitment and would be pleased to offer you admission to School_B. We look forward to welcoming you to our community.
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority ranking is E > B > C > D > A. In this round, I have applications from C and D. Between them, C is ranked higher than D, but I already rejected C earlier in this round’s history, so C is no longer a viable option for me. I still have quota 1 and no current match. While holding out for Student_E or Student_B could yield a better match, there is no guarantee they will apply to School_B (Student_E’s last choice is School_B; Student_B’s second choice is School_B after School_A). Student_D has School_B as first choice and is ready to commit immediately, making acceptance a secure fill within my priority list and avoids risking ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m very interested in joining your school community. I believe I would be a strong fit and would be excited to commit if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.

School_A ranks me 1st, and it is still my 3rd true choice—very strong chance of immediate acceptance and a guaranteed match at a highly preferred school. I will apply to School_A now to lock in a strong outcome rather than gamble on School_C.

Dear Student_E,

There is no higher-ranked candidate to wait for, and delaying risks losing Student_E to School_C or School_D (both rank School_A as 3rd, so they may still prefer other schools but could match elsewhere if accepted). Best action is immediate acceptance.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions Committee—I'm Student_C and I’m formally applying. School_D is one of my top choices because I value its academic rigor and supportive community, and I’m excited about the opportunity to contribute both in and out of the classroom. If admitted, I would be enthusiastic to attend and fully commit. Thank you for your consideration.

Since I was rejected by School_B and there may be no better options left, I should apply now to secure a match rather than risk ending unmatched. I will emphasize fit and commitment while keeping the message concise and respectful.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for your clear enthusiasm for School_D’s academic rigor and community. We are pleased to offer you admission.

If you choose to enroll, we’re excited to welcome you and will follow up with next steps.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: Student_C is 3rd on School_D's true priority list (after Student_D and Student_A). With quota 1 and no current match, accepting Student_C now secures a relatively high-priority student. Waiting risks ending up unmatched or having to accept a lower-priority student (Student_E or Student_B) if higher-priority students never apply. Given Student_C is applying and indicates strong commitment, accept.
